nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Sitting Down at the Table
nodes.text: You and your co-parent sit across from each other. The goal today is simple on paper: agree on a basic weekly routine for your child.

choices.label: Open with appreciation and a clear goal.
choices.text: You start with: “Thank you for meeting. I’d like us to leave with one clear plan for school days and weekends.”

choices.label: Open with frustration about the past weeks.
choices.text: You start with: “This can’t keep going like it has. The last few weeks have been a mess.”

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: What the Child Needs
nodes.text: Your co-parent takes a breath. “Look… I just want her mornings to be calmer. She’s tired and keeps saying she doesn’t know where she’ll wake up.”

choices.label: Reflect back their concern and link it to structure.
choices.text: You reply: “I hear you. Calm mornings matter. Maybe we start with fixed school-night rules, then build from there?”

choices.label: Point out everything they’re doing wrong.
choices.text: You answer: “She’s confused because you keep changing pickup times. That’s on you.”

nodes.speaker: Mediator
nodes.title: Drafting the First Agreement
nodes.text: The mediator leans in. “Let’s write one concrete agreement you both can live with for the next two weeks. We can adjust later if needed.”

choices.label: Propose a simple, testable plan.
choices.text: You suggest: “For the next two weeks, school nights are with you, weekends alternate. We text each Sunday to confirm pick-up times.”

choices.label: Push for a perfect long-term solution now.
choices.text: You insist on finalizing holidays, vacations, and every tiny detail today. The room tightens again.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of Scene – First Agreements
nodes.text: By the end of the meeting, you either leave with a small, workable plan or at least a clearer sense of what still blocks agreement. Either way, this was a step forward from reacting text by text.
